content:
I cannot predict the future, but it is possible that widescale automation may lead to a shift towards a more leisure-focused society, where people work fewer hours and have more time to pursue leisure activities or explore creative endeavors. this would depend on a number of factors, such as the pace of automation, the adoption rate, and the social and economic policies that shape how the benefits of automation are distributed.

it is argued that automation may make certain jobs obsolete and contribute to wage stagnation for certain skills, while at the same time increasing productivity, economic growth and output, and potentially creating new jobs. if implemented in a responsible and equitable manner, automation could lead to greater work-life balance, higher standards of living and a more innovation-driven society.

however, it is also important to consider that the transition towards such a society could be a challenging one, and policymakers and businesses will need to work to ensure that everyone in society benefits from these changes, not just a select few. additionally, there is the question of psychological fulfillment and how people define their purpose without having traditional jobs to rely on.
